title: 111_s333
content: ABOVE-THE-LINE DEDUCTION FOR INTEREST ON INDEBTEDNESS RELATED TO MOTOR VEHICLE PURCHASES. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for a new qualified motor vehicle interest deduction for interest paid on motor vehicle indebtedness. The new amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for a deduction on interest accrued on qualified motor vehicle indebtedness incurred between November 12, 2008, and January 1, 2010, and secured by the vehicle. This deduction also applies to refinanced indebtedness, with a limit on the amount refinanced. The deduction for interest on qualified motor vehicle indebtedness is subject to a dollar limitation of $49,500 ($24,750 for married individuals filing separately) and an income limitation based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The deduction for interest on qualified motor vehicle indebtedness is limited to $125,000 ($250,000 for joint returns) based on modified adjusted gross income. A qualified motor vehicle includes passenger automobiles or light trucks acquired for personal use between November 12, 2008, and January 1, 2010. The deduction for interest on qualified motor vehicle indebtedness is limited to $125,000 ($250,000 for joint returns) based on modified adjusted gross income. It includes passenger automobiles or light trucks acquired for personal use between November 12, 2008, and January 1, 2010, with a gross vehicle weight rating of not more than 8,500 pounds. The deduction is allowed above-the-line and must be reported as qualified motor vehicle interest. SEC. 6050X requires returns to be filed for qualified motor vehicle interest received in trade or business from individuals. SEC. 6050X mandates that any person engaged in a trade or business who receives $600 or more in interest for any calendar year on indebtedness secured by a qualified motor vehicle must file a return with the individual's name and address as prescribed by the Secretary. The term 'person' under SEC. 6050X includes governmental units and their agencies or instrumentalities. Special rules apply to governmental units, exempting them from certain requirements and specifying that returns must be filed by the appropriate officer or employee. Every person required to make a return under subsection (a) must provide a written statement to each individual listed in the return, including the name, address, and phone number of the information contact, and the total interest received. This statement must be given by January 31 of the following year. Every person required to make a return under subsection (a) must furnish a statement to each individual listed in the return by January 31 of the following year. Amendments have been made to penalties related to certain sections of the Code. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include redesignating clauses and inserting new clauses related to returns on qualified motor vehicle interest received in trade or business from individuals. Penalties have been updated for certain sections of the Code. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include updating penalties for sections related to qualified motor vehicle interest received in trade or business from individuals. A new item is added to the table of sections for subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61. SEC. 6050X: Returns for qualified motor vehicle interest received in trade or business from individuals. Effective Date: Amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. SEC. 2: Above-the-line deduction for state sales tax and excise tax on certain motor vehicles. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified motor vehicle taxes as a deduction. This includes State or local sales or excise taxes on the purchase of a qualified motor vehicle. The deduction is subject to an income limitation. The deduction for qualified motor vehicle taxes in the taxable year is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a limit of $125,000 ($250,000 for joint returns). Modified adjusted gross income is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income plus any excluded income under specific sections. The deduction for qualified motor vehicle taxes is not included in the cost of acquired property. Coordination with general sales tax is not applicable if a taxpayer elects under paragraph (5) for the taxable year. Conforming amendments exclude State or local sales or excise taxes paid in connection with the acquisition of property. The deduction for qualified motor vehicle taxes is allowed above-the-line under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction is not included in the cost of acquired property and can be reduced by any taxes for which a deduction is allowed under section 164(a). The amendments made by this section are effective immediately. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008.
